articles.author: karaa
articles.description:
Handling concurrency in your Django applications? Then you‚Äôll want to make friends with select_for_update(). This handy ORM method helps lock database rows during a transaction, ensuring that your data stays consistent‚Äîeven under high load.
Let‚Äôs break it down with a real-world use case.
üîç What Is select_for_update()?
It‚Äôs especially useful for:
Inventory systems
Bank transfers
Purchasing Ticket
Preventing double submission
üõí Example: Locking a Product Row During Checkout
Here‚Äôs how to use select_for_update():
from django.db import transaction
from .models import Product

def purchase_product(product_id, quantity):
    with transaction.atomic():
        product = Product.objects.select_for_update().get(id=product_id)

        if product.stock >= quantity:
            product.stock -= quantity
            product.save()
            return True
        else:
            return False

What‚Äôs happening here?
We start a transaction using transaction.atomic().
We lock the product row with select_for_update().
The row stays locked until the block exits.
‚öôÔ∏è Advanced Usage
Product.objects.select_for_update(nowait=True).get(id=product_id)

nowait=True: raises an error if the row is already locked.


skip_locked=True: skips locked rows entirely (useful for task queues).



üß† Final Thoughts
select_for_update() wisely.
Want to take your Django database handling to the next level? Start by locking smarter. üîí
üí¨ Got questions or use cases? Drop them in the comments‚Äîlet‚Äôs nerd out about transactions and Django internals.
articles.title: üöÄ Mastering select_for_update() in Django: Prevent Race Conditions the Right Way

articles.author: Raghava Chellu
articles.description:
Pygcli


pygcli is a versatile command-line toolkit designed to seamlessly unify Linux shell commands, Google Cloud operations, and Python workflows ‚Äî all through a single, intuitive NPM package. Whether you're scripting automation tasks, interacting with cloud storage, or running Python scripts with arguments, pygcli bridges the gap between development and operations. Developers can execute familiar Linux commands directly from Node.js, upload files to Google Cloud Storage with ease, and trigger Python scripts as part of integrated workflows.
Run Linux shell commands from Node.js
Upload files to Google Cloud Storage
Trigger Python scripts with arguments
npm install -g pygcli

pygcli shell "ls -la"
pygcli upload ./file.txt your-bucket-name
pygcli python script.py arg1 arg2

node examples/s‚Ä¶
articles.title: Unified Cloud & Shell Automation with pygcli

articles.author: Thibaut Flat-Patrick
articles.description:
Originally published at nfolyo blog
We do not learn from experience‚Ä¶ we learn from reflecting on experience. ‚Äî John Dewey
nFolyo is a portfolio tracking and analysis tool built for long-term investors like us ‚Äî with global portfolios invested across equities and ETFs, not just limited to US and EU markets.
It started as a collection of Python scripts and spreadsheets we used to manage our own portfolios. Over time, it evolved into a full-featured tool and became our learning ground for modern web development and microservice architectures.
We released our MVP in November 2024 after eight months of intense development. After iterating on early user feedback, we released version 0.4.0 in March 2025 with several improvements. Now, we're at a turning point that requires us to rethink our appro‚Ä¶
articles.title: nFolyo MVP Postmortem - What We Learned Building a Portfolio Tracker

articles.author: Daniel | Frontend developer
articles.description:
A lot of devs think Linux is only for backend people. Or sysadmins. Or those scary DevOps folks who live in Vim and wear black hoodies.
But here‚Äôs the truth:
If you write code, ship software, or debug anything in production ‚Äî learning Linux will save your life at least once.
Let‚Äôs talk about why.
Even if you develop on Windows or macOS, your app is probably going to run on a Linux server, container, or cloud instance.
If you don‚Äôt understand how Linux works, you‚Äôre flying blind in production.
Ever watched a senior dev move faster with five terminal commands than a junior clicking through four GUIs?
It‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs just Linux basics:
grep, find, awk, sed

Navigating logs
Killing processes
Monitoring memory/CPU usage
Small things. Big unlock.
Your app works locally? Cool.

It crashes on‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why Developers Should Learn Linux (Even Just a Little)

articles.author: Sabin Abrah
articles.description:
React is one of the most powerful tools for building modern web applications. Created by Facebook, it helps developers build fast, dynamic, and responsive user interfaces. If you‚Äôre just starting out with web development or looking to explore something new, React is a great place to begin.
The beauty of React lies in its component-based structure. You build small, reusable parts of the UI called components. These components can be combined and reused throughout your app, making development faster and your code easier to maintain.
To start working with React, the first step is to install Node.js and npm (Node Package Manager) on your system. These tools help you manage your project‚Äôs dependencies and run your development server. Once installed, you can set up a new React project using a too‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to Use React to Build a Web Project ‚Äì A Beginner‚Äôs Guide

articles.author: shiva shanker
articles.description:
Hey fellow developers! üëã
Remember when we used to argue about whether to use Create React App or Next.js? Well, buckle up because React Server Components (RSCs) are about to change everything we know about building React applications.
I've been experimenting with RSCs for the past few months, and honestly? I'm both excited and slightly terrified by how much they're going to reshape our development workflow. Let me share what I've learned and why I think this is the biggest shift in React since hooks.
Imagine if your React components could run on the server, fetch data directly from your database, and send fully rendered HTML to the browser - all while still being interactive where it matters. That's essentially what React Server Components do.
But here's the kicker: they're not replacing ‚Ä¶
articles.title: React Server Components: The Future of Full Stack React

articles.author: Dalton A. Breshears, J.D.
articles.description:
AI is making its mark not just in law firms‚Äîbut also in law schools, where it's becoming a powerful tool for helping students learn faster, write better, and prepare for real-world legal practice.
Smarter Legal Writing and Research: Law students are now using AI-powered platforms like Lexis+ AI, Westlaw Precision, and Casetext CoCounsel to assist with case law research, brief drafting, and citation formatting. These tools don‚Äôt just provide sources‚Äîthey help students understand legal reasoning faster by offering plain-language explanations and suggestions.
AI as a Personal Legal Tutor: Some professors and schools are integrating AI chatbots like ChatGPT to help students refine arguments, practice exam questions, and get real-time feedback on their reasoning. It‚Äôs like having a virtual TA on call 24/7.
Enhanced Classroom Learning: AI tools can generate hypothetical cases, simulate negotiations, or assist in moot court prep. Instructors are also using generative AI to personalize content, quiz prep, and course materials.
With law firms increasingly relying on AI, students are learning to use these tools early‚Äîso they‚Äôre practice-ready from day one. Knowing how to collaborate with AI is becoming a core skill, not just a tech bonus.
AI is becoming an essential companion in legal education. By integrating these tools into their learning process, students are gaining a head start on the tech-driven future of law‚Äîbuilding confidence, efficiency, and a modern skill set before they even step into practice.
Created By: Dalton Breshears
articles.title: How AI Is Transforming Legal Education in Law Schools
